It was hoped that ahotter better feeling was now being engendered amongst the Arabs, and at the recent meeting in Cairo all the political, military and air experts recommended the opening of the desert route at once with a view to strengthening the friendly tribal fooling towards us.
It was proposed to develop the route gradually by ? forward from each and by stages of 50 miles or so, and to form at those stages small stores of petrol, etc. until the whole gap across the desert had been bridged. These small stores would have no personnel but be simply places where planes could come down and refill if necessary. The Arabs could look after ? small depots and would get a certain amount of pay for such work and so come to look upon tho air force as a valuable friend. Before a Commercial Air Service to the East could be established it was essential that the desert route should be developed as a first stop and then at a later date the Royal Air Force and the commercial planes would be of mutual assistance.
At present on the west end of the route no advance had been made beyond Amnan, but at the Eastern end about 3 stages had been prospected: there was also a railway survey party reconnoitring for a rail and pipe-line route across the desert and it had been suggested to them that they might find the present chance a suitable opportunity for pushing on with their work.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs considered that the precedents quotod were hardly analogous as they were probably undertaken as war measures: the opening of tho desert route now might raise ? political questions not only with the tribes but internationally since so much interest was now taken in mandated territories. It was not proposed to use short distance planes until the long distance ones had thoroughly established the route.
Major Young pointed out that the Eastern portion of the route had no water at all and was quite uninhabited except for occasional moving bands: any trouble which might be expected from the tribes would be from the Palestine end..
The Secretary of State for India remarked that Abdulla was now in Trans-Jordania and would presumably be of help in smoothing the way with the tribs at the Western end: he was of opinion that the scheme should be proceeded with.
Some further discussion then took place in which it was pointed out that all the political officers concerned, including the High Commissioners of Palestine and Mesopotamia, recommended tho inauguration of the scheme now and that they were of opinion that no danger was to be expected; it was also pointed out that whatever risk might be incurred, would be in the section West of ?, an area to which the extension of our air influence had already been sanctioned.
While the sense of the meeting was strongly in favour of not adopting any policy which might tend to increase British commitments the conference agreed that :-
As all export opinion considered that there was no risk, the development of the desert air route to Mesopotamia should be proceeded with on the lines proposed by the Secretary of State for the Colonies.
